data.title: Is Bali, Indonesia worth visiting? Bali as a holiday destination.
data.meta_description: What you will experience culturally as a tourist is authentic and genuine, which is why Bali is such a popular destination.
data.text:
Discovering Bali's breathtaking natural wonders is incomplete without visiting its exotic beaches. With over 300 stunning beaches to choose from in Bali alone, every beach is worth visiting, but you’d need several trips to attempt it!

Engage in watersports activities like surfing while enjoying stunning views of the ocean. We have detailed articles on Bali’s best beaches (including best beaches for families, couples, honeymooners, teenagers, surfing and more!)

5. Gorgeous accommodation in Bali

Looking for a luxurious and private vacation in Bali? The island offers a variety of accommodation options, ranging from budget-friendly hostels to luxury villas and resorts. With stunning views of the island's natural beauty, including its beaches, rice paddies, and jungles, Bali is the perfect place to indulge in luxury while enjoying a relaxing vacation. As a bonus, most villas will have a private swimming pool so you don't have to share with anyone else.`

6. Delicious food in Bali: local delicacies to international cuisine

If you are a foodie traveling to Bali, you are in for a treat when it comes to Balinese cuisine and the Bali international food scene.

The diverse and flavorful food scene with influences from Indonesian, Chinese, Indian, and European cuisines will leave you wanting more. Vegetarians and vegans will find plenty of options too since there is also a thriving vegetarian and vegan food scene. Satisfy your cravings by dining at local warungs (small family-owned restaurants) or go all-out with some fine dining experiences at one of the many luxury resorts and world-class restaurants on the island.

7. Unique Balinese culture in Bali (as rich as Thailand)

One of the key things that makes Bali worth visiting is its unique and vibrant culture. Bali is home to the proud Balinese people, who are always willing to share their rich heritage with tourists.

The culture and religion, which is a beautiful blend of Hinduism, Buddhism, and Animism, can be experienced through local temples, markets, food, or by interacting with the friendly locals. If you're interested in history and traditions, then Bali is definitely on your bucket list.

8. Amazing diving opportunities in Bali

If you are a diving enthusiast or want to learn how to dive in Southeast Asia's paradise Bali is worth visiting. The island offers magnificent diving opportunities with fascinating marine life such as manta rays and sea turtles amidst shipwrecks and coral reefs or visit underwater temples. From beginners to advanced divers can enjoy the dive sites on offer.

9. Friendly locals in Bali

When in Bali, you cannot miss out on experiencing the warmth and hospitality of the Balinese people. Their unique culture is evident in their traditional ceremonies, dances, and festivals which are a treat for the eyes. It's not just about their beautiful culture, but also their friendliness that makes Bali an evergreen destination for travelers. The smiling faces and helpful nature of the locals make it worth visiting Bali time and again.

10. Captivating and beautiful religion

Every day, in every home, every village temple, and thousands of larger temples all over the island, Bali's Hindu religion is expressed in a million daily offerings.

From the smallest religious gesture before starting work to the grandest ceremony like Galungan, Bali's religion inspires many travellers and broadens tolerance and understanding. Religion might not be on the top of your list of reasons to come, but I guarantee it will be a cultural aspect of your holiday you will remember the longest.

11. Bali is an affordable destination

Bali is not only worth visiting but is also an affordable paradise in Southeast Asia. Bali offers a range of accommodations, from budget-friendly hostels to luxury villas with privacy policies that cater to all types of tourists. If you're traveling on a budget or just looking for value in Asia, Bali should be your first place to consider because of its budget-friendly lifestyle.

Having said that, Bali is currently having a debate about how it can move away from being seen as a budget destination and focus more on quality tourism. Leaders in Bali are discussing how they can attract fewer visitors who want to engage more in culture, sustainable and higher-value tourism.

I’m talking about more of the sorts of experiences that Baligram promotes—cultural and natural attractions for thoughtful travelers—so you’re in the right place!

One option Bali’s leaders are discussing is a tax on visitors to discourage bad behaviour and that is sparking quite a debate, as you can imagine!

12. Taking day trips to Nusa Penida or Java from Bali

Looking to get beyond Bali’s hype? Consider taking day trips to nearby islands, such as Nusa Penida, or a side trip to Java from Bali. It's possible to become lost in the hype around Bali and miss experiencing some of its best nearby places.

Taking a day trip or side trip can help you experience the natural wonders that Indonesia has to offer. Nusa Penida has one of the most beautiful nature scenes, with stunning landscapes and crystal-clear waters perfect for snorkeling and diving. Alternatively, head over to Java, where you can find historical places such as the Borobudur temple complex and Mount Bromo.

Many of our readers want to see the Komodo Dragon, but it is not found in Bali. Instead, consider a side trip to the islands to the east of Bali, including Komodo Island and its renowned Komodo National Park. You can also find the Komodo Dragon on the islands of Rintja, Padar, and Flores.

13. There are plenty of health and wellness facilities in Bali

Bali may be famous for its beaches and rice paddies, but it's also a paradise for those seeking health and wellness facilities. The Indonesian island offers something for everyone when it comes to yoga and meditation centers where you can rejuvenate your mind and body. Indulge in spa treatments with organic ingredients to pamper yourself. Make a beeline for healthy food cafes where you can try smoothie bowls made with tropical fruit.

14. Spectacular beach clubs in Bali

Bali is a tropical paradise known for its magnificent beach clubs, which offer alluring views and luxurious amenities. These clubs provide an array of activities, like live music performances and fine dining experiences, that are sure to make your trip unforgettable. While enjoying your favorite cocktail during Bali's stunning sunset view, soak up the relaxed ambiance that embodies Balinese culture.

15. Bali is a year-round destination

Bali's tropical climate makes it a popular destination all year. The island offers breathtaking scenery like lush rice paddies and stunning beaches that make it worth visiting for any traveler at any time of the year.

I explore the options for the best time to visit Bali and dive even deeper in our article for the best month to visit Bali so if you are just in the planning stages, you’ll want to check these articles out.

16. Bali has heaps of great shopping opportunities

I don't want to preach, but I’m just saying it because there have been a few problems lately with naughty tourists!

When exploring Bali's natural wonders and stunning scenery, I always try to remember to respect the local customs and traditions.

Things like proper attire for temple visits and removing shoes before entering a temple are important. We can also avoid using our feet to point at or touch anything, as it is considered impure. Even pointing with a finger is considered inappropriate (Balinese will point with a thumb or indicate direction with a nod of the head).

Tourists should also consider supporting local businesses by bargaining respectfully and paying fair prices while shopping at vibrant markets. Sure, we don’t want to be ripped off either, but there’s a happy price - that’s when you and the merchant are happy!

Lastly, preserving the environment by avoiding littering or any activity harming wildlife and their habitats is a must-do in Bali. Sure, the locals generate a huge amount of litter and struggle with how to manage it, but that does not mean we as guests can't make the extra effort to be super good at keeping Bali clean.

2. Travel sustainably

Traveling to Bali is an amazing experience that should be undertaken with sustainability in mind. Some tips I try to follow are:

Opt for eco-friendly accommodations that have a commitment to minimize environmental impact by reducing waste and conserving water.

Show support for the local community by shopping at markets and eating at locally owned restaurants.

Take public transportation or rent bicycles to reduce carbon emissions.

Reduce the use of plastics - embrace reusable water bottles and bring a cloth shopping bag.

3. Do your research

To get the most out of your trip to Bali, it's essential to do thorough research beforehand. Begin by finding out when the best time to visit based on weather conditions and avoiding peak tourist seasons.

Make sure you're aware of the visa requirements for Indonesia too. Learning about Balinese culture and customs is vital to ensuring that you don't accidentally offend locals during your stay. Finally, consider what activities you're interested in before you leave home and plan accordingly for an unforgettable trip.

What are the cons of visiting Bali?

While Bali has many attractions, there are some drawbacks to consider. Touristy areas can be overcrowded and traffic-heavy, while infrastructure may not meet Western standards. Visitors should also be wary of scams and petty crime, as well as the risk of getting "Bali Belly" from contaminated food or water.

1. Traffic in Bali can be bad

Getting around Bali can be a bit of a challenge due to the island's infamous traffic jams. During peak hours, you may find yourself stuck in heavy traffic that seems to move at a snail's pace. The island's infrastructure isn't the best either, which adds to the problem. However, with some planning and patience, it's still possible to enjoy all that Bali has to offer.

Remember slow travel? Embrace the pace and take the journey as a chance to rest and revive (if you have a driver, that is!)

To avoid the traffic, consider hiring a motorcycle (while you still can!) or taking taxis or a private car and driver instead of driving yourself. Additionally, many areas, such as Ubud and Canggu, are easily explored on foot or bicycle. But don't be put off visiting because of traffic - it's not that bad. It keeps moving, there’s heaps to see and you'll get there eventually!

2. Scams in Bali: Taxi's, ATM, Money and more

While Bali is undoubtedly worth visiting for its stunning waterfalls and beautiful natural landscapes, tourists should also be aware of potential scams that may occur. These include ATM skimming, dodgy taxi meters, money changing scams and motorbike rental scams among others.

I cover these in my article, ‘Bali Scams: Video Evidence and How To Avoid Being Fleeced’.

Tourists are advised to remain vigilant while keeping their valuables safe at all times to avoid falling prey to such incidents. It's essential to use reputable money changers and rent from trusted businesses while being cautious about pickpocketing or other petty crimes targeting tourists.

3. Bali can be too touristy

Well, as I said earlier, Bali is not too touristy, but it can be touristy at times, and it probably depends on your definition and where you choose to stay. Overcrowding, pollution, and scams are the main issues to consider.

Despite these challenges, Bali still offers natural wonders such as stunning waterfalls and beautiful rice paddies.

For those who have a low tolerance for touristy locations, consider visiting East Bali and North Bali and discovering 'the real Bali'. I think these regions are the next frontier for tourism, so if you can visit soon, you will see them before they become the next hot spot.

4. Bali has too many Instagram influencers

Funny! Well......yes, this has become a bit of a problem, and the media is taking note.

But as long as the influencers keep their clothes on and respect the local laws, which most do, there's nothing wrong with being an influencer in Bali.

Instead of sticking to hotspots like Ubud and Canggu, consider exploring lesser-known areas such as Nusa Penida, Lombok, or East and North Bali, as mentioned above, to avoid the crowds. Visiting during the less-crowded off-season can also help beat the influencer hype.

5. Pollution and noise in Bali

Pollution and noise are two of the biggest issues facing Bali, and this is not just due to the increase in tourism. Overcrowding has led to environmental problems such as plastic pollution and sewage issues. It's important to be mindful of these challenges when exploring Bali's beautiful scenery and taking day trips to nearby destinations like Nusa Penida or Java.

6. You might get Bali Belly

One risk that tourists often face is Bali Belly, an upset stomach caused by contaminated food or water. To avoid getting sick during your stay in Bali, make sure to drink bottled water and avoid ice cubes in drinks. Additionally, always peel fruits before eating them, wash your hands regularly, and carry hand sanitizer with you.

Be prepared by reading our article, ‘What is Bali Belly? A Guide to Causes, Symptoms & Treatment’ and ‘What to do when you get Bali Belly: 6 Step Action Plan’

7. You need a scooter or car to get around Bali (and a license!)

Getting around Bali is best done with a scooter, as it is the most affordable and efficient option—at least, as long as the government does not actually go ahead and ban tourists from hiring them!

Scooter rental shops are widespread throughout the island; however, those who want to rent must have an international driver's license. Balinese authorities are trying to reduce foreigners' scooter rentals due to safety concerns. So make sure you rent from reputable sources only.

Where to stay in Bali

Bali is indeed worth visiting, and when it comes to deciding where to stay on this Indonesian island, the options are endless.

Ubud offers visitors a unique cultural experience with its serene rice paddies and temples, making it an ideal destination for yoga lovers.

Seminyak boasts trendy bars and restaurants, perfect for digital nomads seeking inspiration.

Nusa Dua provides secluded resorts with pristine beaches and world-class amenities that will leave you feeling pampered and rejuvenated.

Meanwhile, Canggu's laid-back surf town vibe and stunning sunsets make it an excellent choice for surfing enthusiasts.

I discuss all the different areas you can stay in Bali and how to choose the best area to stay in with my article, ‘The Best Areas to Stay in Bali’ but here are a few quick tips:

Canggu - A great place to stay in Bali for surfing

If you're planning to visit Bali and are a passionate surfer or just love being around beaches, Canggu is one of the best places to stay at. This beautiful destination has plenty of accommodation options that cater to all types of travelers- from budget-friendly hostels to luxurious villas. You'll be thrilled with the consistent waves that complement your surfing skills perfectly! And when you're not catching waves or sunbathing on the beach, explore the amazing restaurants and bars that Canggu has to offer. With its chilled-out atmosphere and friendly locals, Canggu is a paradise worth visiting in Bali.

Ubud - A great place to stay in Bali for yoga and culture

If you're looking to experience the cultural heart of Bali while immersing yourself in nature, Ubud is definitely worth visiting. Surrounded by lush green rice paddies and jungle forests, Ubud is the perfect spot for yoga enthusiasts or those interested in Balinese culture. With many yoga studios and retreats available at all levels, Ubud caters to every type of traveler. The town also boasts excellent art galleries, museums, and temples where visitors can learn about traditional Balinese art and architecture. Whether you're on a budget or looking for luxury accommodation, you'll find plenty of options in Ubud.

Kuta - A great place to stay in Bali for nightlife

Looking for a place to party while in Bali? Consider staying in Kuta! It's a popular tourist destination that promises an unforgettable night out. From budget-friendly hostels to luxurious resorts, there are plenty of accommodation options available in this bustling area of Bali. Stepping out onto the streets of Kuta will lead you to fantastic dining experiences and exciting shopping opportunities, offering everything from unique souvenirs to high-end fashion pieces. It's also an ideal base to explore other parts of Bali, like Ubud or Seminyak, with ease. Keep in mind that while Kuta can be crowded and noisy, it's worth visiting for its lively atmosphere alone.

Villas - A great accommodation option in Bali

While exploring Bali, consider staying at one of the many villas. They offer privacy, luxury, and space and are perfect for families or groups of friends. From beachfront properties to secluded hilltop retreats, there are a wide range of options to choose from. Immerse yourself in Balinese culture while enjoying amenities like private pools and gardens and private dining as an alternative to a crowded restaurant.

This is a mere taste of all the amazing places to stay in Bali. Find out much more in my comprehensive guide, 'Fresh, New: The Best Areas To Stay In Bali for 2023/24'.

With its stunning natural wonders, Instagram-worthy rice paddies, and gorgeous beaches like Kuta and Seminyak in Bali, you won’t be disappointed in the choices that Bali offers travelers.

Experience Balinese culture by visiting cultural landmarks such as Pura Besakih or immersing yourself in Balinese cuisine with dishes like nasi goreng or babi guling. If you're into adventure activities during your trip itinerary, check out waterfalls like those near Ubud or take a day trip from Bali to Nusa Penida for amazing scenery!

Baligram is all about showcasing the best natural and cultural wonders of Bali and Lombok, so a great place to start is with our feature articles to get a comprehensive set of guides to the best things to do and see.

Here are a couple of highlights:

Exploring Bali's waterfalls

If you're planning a trip to Southeast Asia or Indonesia in particular, then adding Bali to your bucket list is a no-brainer! While you are on your trip, there are plenty of things to do in Bali, like surfing in Canggu or exploring Ubud rice paddies, but one thing you don't want to miss is visiting Bali's stunning waterfalls!

The island has plenty of them, like Tegenungan, Gitgit, and Sekumpul, which have their own charm and picturesque views that will make your jaw drop. It's definitely worth visiting these natural wonders, where you can swim as well as go on hikes while enjoying the scenery around you.

Surfing, snorkeling, and scuba diving in Bali

Bali isn't just about beautiful rice paddies, stunning waterfalls, or delicious cuisine; it also offers incredible opportunities for adventure enthusiasts. Surfing, snorkeling, and scuba diving are some of the top things to do in Bali to experience its beautiful nature up close. Whether you’re a beginner or an experienced surfer, Bali’s waves cater to all levels. From exploring colorful marine life while snorkeling at Menjangan Island to taking a day trip to Nusa Penida, Bali has something for everyone. While enjoying these activities, always remember to respect local rules and regulations.

I am just scratching the surface of all the amazing things there are to see and do in Bali and Lombok. Explore our travel guide to immerse yourself in all the experiences and build your own amazing itinerary with our articles.

Frequently Asked Questions:

Is it a good idea to go to Bali?

Bali has an unbeatable combination of stunning beaches, temples, and cultural experiences. Activities like surfing and yoga retreats, nature to explore, spa and wellness, oceans to dive, and volcanoes to climb make Bali a fit for just about every travel style.

Is Bali a good place to visit?

Bali is a highly recommended tourist destination with stunning beaches, lively nightlife, and cultural experiences. Bali is safe and offers an incredible variety of experiences and attractions. Bali also has an intriguing cultural heritage to discover through temples, dance shows, and local markets.

What are some of the most interesting things to do in Bali?

Bali is mind-blowing. Surf in the morning, pray at a temple before lunch, feast on organic cuisine, and take a dive before cocktails at sunset. The next day, do the rice fields, take in a dance performance, do a cooking class, and party at a nightclub. Or just sit by a resort pool and sip a cocktail.

Bali is worth it, or is it just overhyped?

Bali is definitely worth it and deserves all the hype it gets. From the moment you land to the moment you leave, the variety of things to see and do will impress you. Whether you come for enlightenment, entertainment, learning, exploring, or simply to relax, Bali will definitely be the trip of a lifetime.

Is Bali still worth it in 2023?

Despite the rise in tourism, Bali remains a must-visit destination in 2023. The natural beauty, the amazing people, the stunning accommodations, and the dazzling sunsets are as incredible as they ever were. And as awareness of areas like East and North Bali grows, you can escape the bustle of the tourist hot spots and find your little pocket of paradise very easily.

What is Bali really like? Is Bali Touristy?

While some areas can be touristy, Bali still retains its charm and offers unique experiences for visitors. From temple visits to hiking, surfing, and exploring local cuisine, Bali has much to offer beyond just being an overhyped tourist destination.

Is Bali pretty?

Bali is undeniably beautiful with its lush green rice paddies, stunning beaches, and majestic temples. Its natural beauty is one of the primary reasons why it has become a popular destination for travelers from all over the world. Don't let the negative talk about crowds and built up areas deter you - there is plenty of wilderness for the explorer to discover, including parts few tourists have ever visited.

Is Bali nice to visit?

Yes, Bali is a delightful destination to visit. Bali is safe, the locals are friendly, and the culture is heartwarming. The scenery is breathtaking, the food is delicious, and the shopping is diverse. Add in decadent spa experiences, a colourful arts scene, and sensational beaches, and you’ll have a holiday you will remember forever.

Is Bali a good holiday destination?

Yes, Bali is a fantastic holiday destination. It offers a unique blend of culture, nature, and adventure that appeals to all types of travelers. With its stunning beaches, lush rice paddies, and rich cultural heritage, Bali is truly a destination like no other.

Conclusion: Is Bali worth visiting in 2023/24?

In conclusion, Bali is definitely worth visiting for its stunning natural beauty, amazing beaches, unique culture, delicious food, and affordable prices. Whether you're looking to relax and rejuvenate, indulge in adventure activities, learn an art or craft or practice yoga, Bali has something special for you.

However, if I had to finish with one last reason to visit Bali, it would be the people. You simply won't find a more caring, peaceful, and spiritual community than the Balinese.
